docs.snippet: Douglas Merrill, a vice president for engineering at Google, is leaving the company to become a president for digital at EMI Music, the recorded music division of EMI Group, according to an executive briefed on his move.      Mr. Merrill is the se...
docs.lead_paragraph: Douglas Merrill, a vice president for engineering at Google, is leaving the company to become a president for digital at EMI Music, the recorded music division of EMI Group, according to an executive briefed on his move. Mr. Merrill is the second senior executive to leave Google in two months. In March, Sheryl Sandberg, who was vice president for global sales and operations, left to become chief operating officer at Facebook.

headline.main: Another Executive Leaving Google

headline.main: The Open Way Yahoo Could Do a Search Deal With Google

docs.abstract: If Yahoo let Google sell ads on its search engine, its revenue might increase by 60 percent. But there are likely to be antitrust questions. One way around this would be for Yahoo to create an open system for any company to sell ads on its search pages, a competition Google is likely to win.

docs.snippet: What if Microsoft dropped its bid for Yahoo and bought AOL and MySpace instead? One analyst says that may be a better deal than a target that doesn't want to merge....
docs.lead_paragraph: The flirtations and betrayals among Internet giants would steam up even the hottest afternoon soap opera. In the latest round, the News Corporation, which had been playing footsie with Yahoo, has jumped into the arms of Microsoft in an effort to break up the pending union of Yahoo and Time Warner's estranged wife, AOL. Oh yes, Google, which everyone envies, is prodding all this on to keep its rivals in a state of confusion.

headline.main: Is Yahoo the Odd Man Out?

docs.snippet: It has been a brutal time for companies hoping to go public, with a record number of initial public offerings being withdrawn in the first quarter of 2008. This makes the proposed stock sale of DigitalGlobe, a provider of satellite earth images wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: It has been a brutal time for companies hoping to go public, with a record number of initial public offerings being withdrawn in the first quarter of 2008. This makes the proposed stock sale of DigitalGlobe, a provider of satellite earth images whose customers include the United States government and Google, all the more interesting. Late Monday, the Longmont, Colo.-based company filed to sell as much as $250 million in stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline.main: Study: Google Lost Share of Search Ad Dollars to Yahoo

docs.abstract: A new study by a search marketer suggests that Yahoo's search ad business grew faster than Google's business in the United States in the first quarter. The study by SearchIgnite represents just one of the many data points that investors will be watching for signs of an economic slowdown and the value of the Microsoft-Yahoo deal.

docs.snippet: GOTTEHRER--Barry. We all came of age together--working with Barry for the City we love and its courageous Mayor when New York teetered over the flames that engulfed so many American cities -ignited by race, poverty, Vietnam and the anger of ignore...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOTTEHRER--Barry. We all came of age together--working with Barry for the City we love and its courageous Mayor when New York teetered over the flames that engulfed so many American cities -ignited by race, poverty, Vietnam and the anger of ignored communities. Barry's Bronx street smarts and underdog sensibility were indispensable to our coming through, together. He was our comrade-in-arms, our brother, an unsung New York hero. Our love to those he loved most Pat, Kevin and Andrea. Thanks, Sam Roberts, for the perfect Times obit and moving podcast essay (Google ''an - agent - of - change - at - a time of chaos''). A New York Memorial will be held in June. Lindsay Colleagues of Barry

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTEHRER, BARRY

Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, decided to play an aw-shucks Jimmy Stewart role when asked about the continuing merger talks and the separate prospect of Yahoo handing over its search ads business to Google. docs.snippet: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google....
docs.lead_paragraph: I've been a rather harsh critic of Yahoo's quarterly earnings calls. In January, I called the effort by Jerry Yang and Sue Decker to justify the company's weak performance a "droning, jargon-filled" explication of a "vision-goes-here strategy." Two days later, a letter from Redmond arrived with an offer that Yahoo is still working hard to refuse.

docs.snippet: Rather than building new social networks, Google and Yahoo want to bring "social" features to their own sites and services....
docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to becoming a force in social networks, Google and Yahoo have tried and largely failed. To be sure, Google has Orkut, which is popular in Brazil and the Philippines India, but not the United States. For its part, Yahoo has largely pulled the plug on Yahoo 360. But it is clear that MySpace and Facebook (and Bebo in Britain) remain firmly on top of the social network heap.

docs.snippet: If Microsoft dropped its bid for Yahoo, it would be admitting it couldn't really catch up to Google for consumer Web services. And with $29 billion in the company bank account, Steve Ballmer simply isn't ready to accept that. As a result, it is li...

headline.main: Why Steve Ballmer Will Keep Chasing Yahoo

docs.abstract: If Microsoft dropped its bid for Yahoo, it would be admitting it couldn't really catch up to Google for consumer Web services. And with $29 billion in the company bank account, Steve Ballmer simply isn't ready to accept that. As a result, it is likely to proceed with its bid for Yahoo despite the many risks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft is leading the tech industry's charge up Capitol Hill, according to statistics released Monday.

headline.main: Microsoft Tops Tech's Lobby Spenders

docs.abstract: Microsoft is leading the tech industry's charge up Capitol Hill, according to statistics released Monday. The world's largest software company spent $9 million on lobbyists to make its case in issues including taxes and trade, according to statistics compiled by the Center for Responsive Politics. By contrast, Google, the leading Internet search engine, spent just [...]

docs.snippet: The price of ads plummeted for AOL in the first quarter. Time Warner blames the head of its advertising unit who it fired in March. The good news is only 647,000 people canceled their AOL accounts in the quarter, a lower defection rate than it has...
docs.lead_paragraph: AOL had a shockingly bad first quarter in advertising sales, and the reason was the disarray in its own sales force. Overall ad revenue at AOL was up only 1 percent from a year earlier, its parent company, Time Warner, reported Wednesday. By comparison, ad revenue increased 42 percent at Google, 29 percent at Microsoft and 7 percent at Yahoo (which has its own dissarray.)

headline.main: AOL's Blame Game: The Guy We Fired Did It

docs.abstract: The price of ads plummeted for AOL in the first quarter. Time Warner blames the head of its advertising unit who it fired in March. The good news is only 647,000 people canceled their AOL accounts in the quarter, a lower defection rate than it has had in a long time.

docs.snippet: Cox Enterprises, a media company with broad holdings in newspapers, radio and television, said Tuesday that it would pay $300 million in cash for the advertising technology company Adify. The move would put Cox in competition with companies like G...
docs.lead_paragraph: Cox Enterprises, a media company with broad holdings in newspapers, radio and television, said Tuesday that it would pay $300 million in cash for the advertising technology company Adify. The move would put Cox in competition with companies like Google that have built up big online advertising franchises.

headline.main: Cox Enterprises to Acquire Adify, an Ad Tech Firm

docs.abstract: Cox Enterprises, a media company with broad holdings in newspapers, radio and television, said Tuesday that it would pay $300 million in cash for the advertising technology company Adify. The move would put Cox in competition with companies like Google that have built up big online advertising franchises. Adify, founded in 2005, helps Internet publishers [...]
